content: The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 may be cited as the Act. It includes higher maximum penalties for mail and wire fraud. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002, also known as the Act, increases penalties for mail and wire fraud by amending relevant sections of the United States Code. Additionally, it introduces a new section, 1348, addressing securities fraud. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 enhances penalties for securities fraud, including fines or imprisonment up to 25 years for obtaining money or property through false pretenses in connection with the purchase or sale of registered securities. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 increases penalties for securities fraud, with fines or imprisonment up to 25 years for fraudulent activities related to registered securities. The amendment adds a new section to the United States Code regarding penalties for violations. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 increases penalties for securities fraud, with fines or imprisonment up to 25 years for fraudulent activities related to registered securities. The amendment adds a new section to the United States Code regarding penalties for violations, including tampering with a record or impeding an official proceeding. Section 1512 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include penalties for corruptly altering, destroying, or obstructing records or official proceedings, with fines or imprisonment up to 20 years. The amendment to Section 1512 of title 18, United States Code includes penalties for obstructing official proceedings, with fines or imprisonment up to 20 years. SEC. 4. AMENDMENT TO THE FEDERAL SENTENCING GUIDELINES. The United States Sentencing Commission is requested to promptly review and consider new sentencing guidelines for securities and accounting fraud, specifically targeting officers or directors of publicly traded corporations who commit fraud. The Sentencing Commission is tasked with reviewing and updating sentencing guidelines for securities and accounting fraud committed by officers or directors of publicly traded corporations. They are also required to submit an explanation of their actions to Congress and provide policy recommendations for combating these offenses. The Sentencing Commission is responsible for ensuring that sentencing guidelines for securities, pension, and accounting fraud reflect the seriousness of the offenses and the need for aggressive law enforcement action. They must also consider consistency with other directives, account for aggravating or mitigating circumstances, and adjust offense levels and enhancements as needed. The sentencing guidelines need to be updated to ensure adequate offense levels and enhancements for obstruction of justice and fraud offenses with a significant number of victims. Necessary changes should be made to ensure consistency and effectiveness in sentencing. The United States Sentencing Commission is requested to update guidelines for fraud offenses with over 50 victims, make necessary changes for consistency, and meet sentencing purposes within 120 days of enactment. The United States Sentencing Commission is required to update guidelines for fraud offenses with over 50 victims within 120 days of enactment, following procedures outlined in the Sentencing Reform Act of 1987. SEC. 5. DEBTS NONDISCHARGEABLE IF INCURRED IN VIOLATION OF SECURITIES FRAUD LAWS. Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, is amended to include a new paragraph (19) regarding claims for violations of Federal securities laws, State securities laws, or related regulations. The amendment to Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, includes a new paragraph (19) addressing claims related to violations of Federal or State securities laws, regulations, common law fraud, deceit, or manipulation in connection with the purchase or sale of securities. This amendment covers claims resulting from judgments, orders, consent orders, or decrees in Federal or State judicial or administrative proceedings. The amendment to Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, includes a new paragraph (19) covering claims related to violations of securities laws, regulations, fraud, deceit, or manipulation in securities transactions. This includes judgments, orders, settlement agreements, and court or administrative orders for payments owed by the debtor. SEC. 6. CORPORATE RESPONSIBILITY FOR FINANCIAL REPORTS. SEC. 6. CORPORATE RESPONSIBILITY FOR FINANCIAL REPORTS. Amends Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code by adding a new section requiring corporate officers to certify financial reports filed with the Securities Exchange Commission. The new section added to Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code requires corporate officers to certify that financial statements accurately represent the issuer's operations and financial condition. Violations of this section can result in criminal penalties of fines up to $5,000,000 or imprisonment up to 20 years. The new section added to Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code imposes criminal penalties of fines up to $5,000,000 or imprisonment up to 20 years for corporate officers who fail to certify accurate financial statements. SEC. 7. ATTEMPTS AND CONSPIRACIES TO COMMIT CRIMINAL OFFENSES. Any person who attempts or conspires to commit any offense against the United States shall be subject to the same penalties as those prescribed for the offense. SEC. 8 amends the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to increase criminal penalties, raising the maximum fine to $5,000,000 and maximum imprisonment to 20 years. SEC. 9 grants temporary freeze authority to the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to grant temporary freeze authority to the Securities and Exchange Commission during lawful investigations involving possible violations of federal securities laws by publicly traded securities issuers or related individuals. The Securities and Exchange Commission can petition a Federal district court for a temporary order to escrow extraordinary payments to certain individuals for 45 days during investigations of possible violations of federal securities laws by publicly traded securities issuers. The Securities and Exchange Commission can request a court order to hold payments in an interest-bearing account for 45 days during investigations of securities law violations. The order requires notice and a hearing unless impracticable or against public interest. The Securities and Exchange Commission can issue a temporary order that becomes effective immediately, serves the parties involved, and remains enforceable for 45 days unless modified by a court. Extensions can be authorized. The Securities and Exchange Commission can issue a temporary order that remains effective and enforceable for 45 days, with the possibility of a 45-day extension upon court approval for a total period not exceeding 90 days. Violations can be charged if the issuer or other party fails to comply. If violations of the Federal securities laws are charged before the expiration of a temporary order, the order will remain in effect until the legal proceedings are concluded. The affected issuer or person can petition the court for review of the order if legal proceedings are concluded. If no violations are charged before the temporary order expires, it remains in effect until legal proceedings are over. The temporary order under subparagraph (A) will terminate at the end of the 45-day effective period, and disputed payments will be returned to the issuer or affected person. Additionally, a technical amendment is made to Section 21C(c)(2) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. SEC. 10. AUTHORITY OF THE COMMISSION TO PROHIBIT PERSONS FROM SERVING AS OFFICERS OR DIRECTORS. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 allows the Commission to prohibit individuals who have violated certain regulations from serving as officers or directors of registered issuers. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 empowers the Commission to bar individuals who have violated regulations from being officers or directors of registered issuers. The Commission may issue an order in cease-and-desist proceedings to prohibit individuals from serving as officers or directors if their conduct shows they are unfit for such roles. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 allows the Commission to ban individuals who have violated regulations from serving as officers or directors of registered issuers. The Commission can issue an order in cease-and-desist proceedings to prevent individuals from holding such roles if their behavior demonstrates unsuitability. SEC. 11. RETALIATION AGAINST INFORMANT. Amends Section 1513 of title 18, United States Code to penalize retaliation against informants providing truthful information on Federal offenses to law enforcement. Penalties include fines or up to 10 years imprisonment. Passed the House of Representatives on July 16, 2002. Attest: JEFF TRANDAHL, Clerk.
